entry.title: Radio Days
entry.content: 🎥 Radio Days, 1987 ⭐️ ★★★★½ The ensemble cast is excellent across the board, with fun appearance by Mia Farrow and a song by Diane Keaton . A warm, funny, and beautifully woven love letter to a bygone era . 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/radio-days/1/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Milli Vanilli
entry.content: 🎥 Milli Vanilli, 2023 ⭐️ ★★★★ What really makes my blood boil is that they had to return their Grammy awards . Milli Vanilli was an act, and Rob & Fab were part of that act . Honestly, Rob & Fab come out of this film almost unhurt, if not entirely cleared . 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/milli-vanilli/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Evil Under the Sun
entry.content: 🎥 Evil Under the Sun, 1982 ⭐️ ★★★★ Peter Ustinov is at his most charming as Poirot, and supporting turns from Diana Rigg, Maggie Smith, and Denis Quilley are pitch-perfect . Cole Porter soundtrack is an inspired choice, beautifully reorchestrated to match the film’s vintage glamour . 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/evil-under-the-sun/ #FilmReview

entry.title: The Birdcage
entry.content: 🎥 The Birdcage, 1996 ⭐️ ★★★★ Nathan Lane is a whirlwind of emotion and timing, Robin Williams plays it with rare restraint, and Gene Hackman? Totally owning it. A sparkling, sharp, and heartfelt remake that thrives on performance. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/the-birdcage/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Tea and Sympathy
entry.content: 🎥 Tea and Sympathy, 1956 ⭐️ ★★★ Deborah Kerr and John Kerr give sensitive, nuanced performances . The film runs a bit longer than necessary, and starts to stretch in places, but the strength of its story holds steady . 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/tea-and-sympathy/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Victim
entry.content: 🎥 Victim, 1961 ⭐️ ★★★★ Dirk Bogarde delivers a quietly devastating performance . The supporting cast, drawn from the finest of the British stage and screen, is uniformly excellent . 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/victim/ #FilmReview

entry.title: The Ritz
entry.content: 🎥 The Ritz, 1976 ⭐️ ★★½ Moreno steals every scene she’s in, injecting just enough energy to keep things afloat . The film has a few genuinely funny moments, but they’re too scattered to give it real momentum . 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/the-ritz/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Rebecca
entry.content: 🎥 Rebecca, 1940 ⭐️ ★★★★★ The film bears his fingerprints in every frame . From the first eerie shots of Manderley to the final blaze, this is unmistakably Hitchcock . 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/rebecca/1/ #FilmReview

entry.title: Mission: Impossible – The Final Reckoning
entry.content: 🎥 Mission: Impossible – The Final Reckoning, 2025 ⭐️ ★★★½ Even as a standalone, this would’ve been a smash hit. The action is spectacular, the locations are stunning, and the set pieces are jaw-dropping. But what makes it click is that it’s not just explosions, there’s strategy, suspense, and just the right dash of humor. 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/mission-impossible-the-final-reckoning/ #FilmReview

entry.title: The Three Musketeers
entry.content: 🎥 The Three Musketeers, 1973 ⭐️ ★★★½ The first part leans heavily on action, and while not all the fight sequences are particularly well executed, when they are done with humor and flair, it’s pure delight . What really holds the film together is the star-studded cast, all clearly having a blast . 🔗 https://letterboxd.com/julienpierre/film/the-three-musketeers-1973/1/ #FilmReview
